Bibliography of science fiction, fantasy, historical fiction and nonfiction writer '''[[L. Sprague de Camp]]''':
==Science fiction== ===The ''Viagens Interplanetarias''=== {{main|Viagens Interplanetarias}}
*'''Krishna''' **"[[Finished (short story)|Finished]]" (1949 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) **"[[Perpetual Motion (novella)|Perpetual Motion]]" (1950 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953) and ''The Queen of Zamba'' (1977)) **''[[The Queen of Zamba]]'' (1949 - collected in ''The Queen of Zamba'' (1977)) [vt ''[[Cosmic Manhunt]]'' (1954)], {{ISBN|0-441-69658-9}} **"[[Calories (story)|Calories]]" (1951 - collected in ''Sprague de Camp's New Anthology of Science Fiction'' (1953)) **''[[The Hand of Zei]]'' (1950), {{ISBN|0-671-69865-6}} **''[[The Hostage of Zir]]'' (1977) **''[[The Prisoner of Zhamanak]]'' (1982) **''[[The Virgin of Zesh]]'' (1953 - collected in ''The Virgin & the Wheels'' (1976) and ''The Virgin of Zesh & The Tower of Zanid'' (1982)), {{ISBN|0-441-86495-3}} **''[[The Bones of Zora]]'' (1983) (with [[Catherine Crook de Camp]]) **''[[The Tower of Zanid]]'' (1958 - collected in ''The Virgin of Zesh & The Tower of Zanid'' (1982)), {{ISBN|0-441-86495-3}} **''[[The Swords of Zinjaban]]'' (1991) (with [[Catherine Crook de Camp]]) *'''Earth''' **"[[The Colorful Character]]" (1949 - collected in ''Sprague de Camp's New Anthology of Science Fiction'' (1953)) **"[[The Inspector's Teeth]]" (1950 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953) and ''The Best of L. Sprague de Camp'' (1978)) **"[[The Continent Makers]]" (1951 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) *'''Osiris''' **"[[Summer Wear]]" (1950 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) **"[[Git Along!]]" (1950 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) *'''Vishnu''' **"[[The Galton Whistle]]" (1951 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) **"[[The Animal-Cracker Plot]]" (1949 - collected in ''The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens'' (1953)) *'''Ormazd''' **''[[Rogue Queen]]'' (1951) *'''Kukulkan''' **''[[The Stones of Nomuru]]'' (1988) (with [[Catherine Crook de Camp]]) **''[[The Venom Trees of Sunga]]'' (1992) *'''Collections''' **''[[The Continent Makers and Other Tales of the Viagens]]'' (1953) **''[[The Queen of Zamba]]'' (1977) **''[[The Virgin of Zesh & The Tower of Zanid]]'' (1983)
===Reginald Rivers=== *"[[A Gun for Dinosaur]]" (1956 - collected in ''A Gun for Dinosaur and Other Imaginative Tales'' (1963), ''The Best of L. Sprague de Camp'' (1978), ''Rivers of Time'' (1993), ''Aristotle and the Gun and Other Stories'' (2002) and ''Years in the Making: the Time-Travel Stories of L. Sprague de Camp'' (2005)) *"The Cayuse" (1993 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"Crocamander Quest" (1992 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"Miocene Romance" (1993 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"The Synthetic Barbarian" (1992 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"The Satanic Illusion" (1992 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"The Big Splash" (1992 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993)) *"The Mislaid Mastodon" (1993 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993) and ''Aristotle and the Gun and Other Stories'' (2002)) *"The Honeymoon Dragon" (1993 - collected in ''Rivers of Time'' (1993) and ''Aristotle and the Gun and Other Stories'' (2002)) *''[[Rivers of Time]]'' (collection) (1993)
===Johnny Black=== *"[[The Command (short story)|The Command]]" (1938 - collected in ''The Best of L. Sprague de Camp'' (1978); rewritten as "The Bear Who Saved the World" (1977, with Catherine Crook de Camp)) *"[https://archive.org/stream/Astounding_v22n05_1939-01_FireBellyFireBelly#page/n81/mode/2up The Incorrigible]" (1939) *"The Emancipated" (1940) *"The Exalted" (1940)
===Drinkwhiskey Institute=== *"Some Curious Effects of Time Travel" (1942 - collected in ''Scribblings'' (1972)) *"The Anecdote of the Negative Wugug" (1942 - collected in ''Scribblings'' (1972)) *"The Anecdote of the Movable Ears" (1943 - collected in ''Scribblings'' (1972)) *"The Lusts of Professor Adams" (1972 - collected in ''Scribblings'' (1972))
===Other science fiction novels and collections=== *''[[Lest Darkness Fall]]'' (1941 - collected in ''Years in the Making: the Time-Travel Stories of L. revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Robert Maskell Patterson#Cryptology]] [[Category:Letters (message)]] [[Category:1801 documents]]

{{refimprove|date=September 2018}} {{IPstack}}
The '''Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution''' ('''LLMNR''') is a protocol based on the [[Domain Name System]] (DNS) packet format that allows both [[IPv4]] and [[IPv6]] hosts to perform name resolution for hosts on the same local link. It is included in [[Windows Vista]], [[Windows Server 2008]], [[Windows 7]], [[Windows 8]] and [[Windows 10]].<ref>[https://technet.microsoft.com/library/bb878128 LLMNR: The Cable Guy]</ref> It is also implemented by [[systemd]]-resolved on Linux.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://lwn.net/Articles/609740/ |title=systemd 216 available |accessdate=2015-08-10}}</ref> LLMNR is defined in RFC 4795.
==Protocol details== In responding to queries, responders listen on [[User Datagram Protocol|UDP]] port 5355 on the following link-scope [[Multicast address]]: * IPv4 - 224.0.0.252, [[MAC address]] 01-00-5E-00-00-FC * IPv6 - FF02:0:0:0:0:0:1:3 (this notation can be abbreviated as FF02::1:3), MAC address 33-33-00-01-00-03 The responders also listen on [[Transmission Control Protocol|TCP]] port 5355 on the [[unicast]] address that the host uses to respond to queries.
== Packet header structure == {| width="700" align="center" |- |
|}
* ID - A 16-bit identifier assigned by the program that generates any kind of query. * QR - Query/Response. * OPCODE - A 4-bit field that specifies the kind of query in this message. This value is set by the originator of a query and copied into the response. This specification defines the behavior of standard queries and responses (opcode value of zero). Future specifications may define the use of other opcodes with LLMNR. * C - Conflict. * TC - TrunCation. * T - Tentative. * Z - Reserved for future use. * RCODE - Response code. * QDCOUNT - An unsigned 16-bit integer specifying the number of entries in the question section. * ANCOUNT - An unsigned 16-bit integer specifying the number of resource records in the answer section. * NSCOUNT - An unsigned 16-bit integer specifying the number of name server resource records in the authority records section. * ARCOUNT - An unsigned 16-bit integer specifying the number of resource records in the additional records section.
== See also == * Network Basic Input/Output System ([[NetBIOS]]) * [[Peer Name Resolution Protocol]] (P[[Multicast DNS|t DNS]] (mDNS) * [[Zero-configuration networking]] (Zeroconf)
== References == <references />
== External links == * Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution, Microsoft TechNet * RFC 4795, Informational, Link-Local Multicast Name Resolution (LLMNR)

revision.text:
{{Infobox software | name = NEPOMUK | title = NEPOMUK | logo = Nepomuk.svg | logo caption = | logo_size = 100px | logo_alt = | screenshot = <!-- Image name is enough --> | caption = | screenshot_size = | screenshot_alt = | collapsible = | author = | developer = | released = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | discontinued = | latest release version = | latest release date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | latest preview version = | latest preview date = <!-- {{Start date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|df=yes/no}} --> | frequently updated = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | status = | programming language = [[C++]], [[Java (programming language)|Java]] | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = | language count = <!-- DO NOT include this parameter unless you know what it does --> | language footnote = | genre = [[Semantic desktop]] | license = Various ([[BSD]]-style preferred)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dev.nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org/wiki/NepomukLicense|title=Nepomuk License|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090429050153/http://dev.nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org/wiki/NepomukLicense|archivedate=2009-04-29|df=}}</ref> | alexa = | website = {{Plainlist| *{{URL|http://nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org}} *{{URL|http://nepomuk.kde.org}} }} | standard = | AsOf = }}
'''NEPOMUK''' (Networked Environment for Personal, [[Ontology]]-based Management of Unified Knowledge) is an open-source software specification that is concerned with the development of a social [[semantic desktop]] that enriches and interconnects data from different desktop applications using semantic [[metadata]] stored as [[Resource Description Framework|RDF]]. Between 2006 and 2008 it was funded by a European Union research project of the same name<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cordis.europa.eu/fetch?CALLER=PROJ_ICT&ACTION=D&DOC=1&CAT=PROJ&QUERY=011ca2def8a7:ccd3:321e9807&RCN=79390|title=European Commission : CORDIS : Projects & Results Service : Networked environment for personal ontology-based management of unified knowledge|publisher=}}</ref> that grouped together industrial and academic actors to develop various Semantic Desktop technologies.
== Implementations == Three active implementations of NEPOMUK exist: A [[C++]]/[[KDE]]-based variant, a [[Java (programming language)|Java]]-based variant, and a commercial version. More versions were created during the EU project between 2006 and 2008, some active beyond the project.<ref>[http://www.gnowsis.com/about/blog/2010/11/20/how-does-gnowsis-relate-nepomuk-and-others How Does Gnowsis Relate to NEPOMUK and Others?] Blogpost dated 20.11.2010. Written by Leo Sauermann who contributed to the NEPOMUK project. 6 implementations of NEPOMUK are listed</ref>
=== KDE === ''NEPOMUK-KDE'' was originally featured as one of the newer technologies in [[KDE Software Compilation 4]].<ref>[http://nepomuk.kde.org/ NEPOMUK-KDE project]</ref> It used [[Soprano (KDE)|Soprano]] as the main RDF data storage and parsing library, while handling ontology imports through the [[Redland RDF Application Framework|Raptor parser plugin]] and the [[Redland RDF Application Framework|Redland storage plugin]]; all RDF data was stored by [[Virtuoso Universal Server|Virtuoso]] which also handled full-text indexing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://trueg.wordpress.com/2011/09/22/about-strigi-soprano-virtuoso-clucene-and-libstreamanalyzer/|title=About Strigi, Soprano, Virtuoso, CLucene, and Libstreamanalyzer|first=Sebastian|last=Trüg|date=22 September 2011|publisher=}}</ref> On a technical level, NEPOMUK-KDE allowed associating metadata to various items present on a normal user's desktop such as files, bookmarks, e-mails, and calendar entries. Metadata could be arbitrary RDF. Tagging is the most user-visible metadata application.
As the KDE SC 4 series of releases progressed, it became apparent that NEPOMUK was not delivering the performance and user experience that had initially been anticipated. As a result of this, in KDE SC 4.13 a new indexing and semantic search technology ''Baloo'' was introduced, with a short transition period allowing applications to be ported and data to be migrated before the removal of NEPOMUK.<ref>{{cite web|title=KDE's Next Generation Semantic Search|url=http://dot.kde.org/2014/02/24/kdes-next-generation-semantic-search|accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=KDE Community Wiki - Baloo|url=http://community.kde.org/Baloo|accessdate=2014-06-28}}</ref> Baloo initially used [[SQLite]] but currently uses [[Lightning Memory-Mapped Database|LMDB]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Baloo 5.15|url=http://vhanda.in/blog/2015/10/baloo-5-15/|accessdate=2015-10-11}}</ref> for storage, and [[Xapian]] for searching.
=== Zeitgeist === The [[Zeitgeist (framework)|Zeitgeist]] framework, used by [[GNOME]] and Ubuntu's [[Unity (user interface)|Unity user interface]], uses the NEPOMUK ontology, as does the [[Tracker (search software)|Tracker]] search engine.
=== Java === The Java-based implementation of NEPOMUK<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dev.nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org/|title=Semantic Desktop[.]org|first=Tudor|last=Groza|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071201200408/http://dev.nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org/|archivedate=2007-12-01|df=}}</ref> was finished at the end of 2008 and served as a proof-of-concept environment for several novel semantic desktop techniques. It features its own frontend (''PSEW'') that integrates search, browsing, recommendation, and peer-to-peer functionality. The Java implementation uses the [[Sesame (framework)|Sesame]] RDF store and the Aperture<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aperture.sourceforge.net/|title=Aperture Framework|first=Leo Sauermann, Christiaan|last=Fluit|publisher=}}</ref> framework for integrating with other desktop applications such as mail clients and browsers.
A number of artifacts have been created in the context of the Java research implementation: * WikiModel<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikimodel.sourceforge.net/|title=Welcome to the framework!|publisher=}}</ref>
=== Refinder by Gnowsis === Implementation of the commercial [[Software as a service]] product ''Refinder''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getrefinder.com|title=Home - Refinder|publisher=}}</ref> started in 2009 and a limited beta-version was released in December 2010.<ref>[http://www.futurezone.at/stories/1664740/ Refinder: Das nächste Level des Hyperlinks] Article in Futurezone by Jakob Steinschaden, 3.12.2010.</ref> ''Refinder'' was developed by Gnowsis, a spin-off company of the [[German Research Centre for Artificial Intelligence| German Research Centre for Artificial Intelligence (DFKI)]] (project lead in the NEPOMUK EU project). The start-up was shut down in late 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.getrefinder.com/about/blog/2013/11/09/we-are-shutting-refinder-down|title=We are shutting Refinder down - Refinder|publisher=}}</ref> with no plans to make the implementation code available.
''Refinder'' uses the same data formats as the other implementations, but using [[Software as a service]] instead of the desktop approach of the other implementations.
== Data formats == * PIMO — the data format used for describing a Personal Information Model, describing Persons, Projects, Topics, Events, etc., also used in NEPOMUK-KDE.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.semanticdesktop.org/ontologies/2007/11/01/pimo/|title=Personal Information Model (PIMO)|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228042334/http://www.semanticdesktop.org/ontologies/2007/11/01/pimo/|archivedate=2008-12-28|df=}}</ref> * NIE — the NEPOMUK Information Element Ontology (and the associated ontologies NFO etc.), describing resources on a desktop (files, mails, etc.)<ref>[http://www.semanticdesktop.org/ontologies/nie/ NEPOMUK Information Element Ontology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230072038/http://www.semanticdesktop.org/ontologies/nie/ |date=2008-12-30 }}</ref>
== See also == * [[Tracker (search software)]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * {{Official website|http://nepomuk.semanticdesktop.org/}} * [http://www.internetnews.com/dev-news/article.php/3688606 Article: Open Source Semantic Desktop Is Coming] * [http://www.technologyreview.com/computing/21840/?a=f MIT Technology Review: Semantic Sense for the Desktop] * [http://tech.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=08%2F12%2F16%2F1546219&from=rss Slashdot story about Nepomuk] * [http://nepomuk.kde.org/ NEPOMUK in KDE]
{{KDE}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Nepomuk (Framework)}} [[Category:KDE Frameworks]] [[Category:KDE Platform]] [[Category:Personal information managers]] [[Category:Semantic desktop]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{for|ORCID use on Wikipedia|Wikipedia:ORCID}}
{{Infobox identifier | image = ORCID logo with tagline.svg | image_border = no | name = ORCID | full_name = Open Researcher and Contributor ID | start_date = {{start date and age|2012|10|16|df=yes|paren=yes}} | organisation = ORCID, Inc. | number = <!-- Please do not update this figure... -->5,641,303<!-- ...without also updating it in the body of the article --> | digits = 16 | check_digit = MOD 11-2 | example = <nowiki>https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097</nowiki> | website = {{URL|orcid.org}} }}
The '''ORCID''' '''iD''' ('''Open Researcher and Contributor ID''') is a nonproprietary [[alphanumeric code]] to uniquely identify [[scientist|scientific]] and other [[Academic authorship|academic authors]] and contributors.<ref name="Nature09">Editorial (2009). "Credit where credit is due". ''Nature''. 462: 825. {{doi|10.1038/462825a}}.</ref><ref name="ORCID">[http://www.orcid.org ORCID website].</ref><ref name="Nature12">News (30 May 2012) "Scientists: your number is up: ORCID scheme will give researchers unique identifiers to improve tracking of publications", Declan Butler, "Nature". 485: 564 {{doi|10.1038/485564a}}.</ref><ref name="IS">{{cite web |url=http://blog.impactstory.org/ten-things-you-need-to-know-about-orcid-right-now/ |title=Ten things you need to know about ORCID right now |date=10 April 2014 |work=ImpactStory |accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="ChemistryViews.org">Interview with Alice Meadows, Director of Communications for ORCID (2015). "ORCID – Unique Author Identifier". ''ChemViews magazine''. {{doi|10.1002/chemv.201500088}}.</ref> This addresses the problem that a particular author's contributions to the [[scientific literature]] or publications in the [[humanities]] can be hard to recognize as most [[personal name]]s are not unique, they can change ([[Maiden and married names|such as with marriage]]), have cultural differences in name order, contain inconsistent use of first-name abbreviations and employ different [[writing system]]s. It provides a persistent identity for humans, similar to that created for content-related entities on digital networks by [[digital object identifier]]s (DOIs).<ref>[http://www.crossref.org/01company/orcid.html Crossref & ORCID].</ref>
The ORCID organization, ORCID Inc., offers an open and independent registry intended to be the ''de facto'' standard for contributor identification in research and [[academic publishing]]. On 16 October 2012, ORCID launched its registry services<ref name="launchORCID">{{cite web |title=ORCID Launches Registry |url=http://about.orcid.org/news/2012/10/16/orcid-launches-registry |accessdate=18 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=ORCID vs ISNI; ORCID lanceert vandaag hun Author Register - Artikel - SURFspace |url=https://www.surfspace.nl/artikel/936-orcid-vs-isni-orcid-lanceert-vandaag-hun-author-register/ |accessdate=24 October 2012}}</ref> and started issuing user identifiers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Register for an ORCID iD |url=http://orcid.org/register |accessdate=18 October 2012}}</ref>
==Development and launch== ORCID was first announced in 2009 as a collaborative effort by the research community "to resolve the author name ambiguity problem in scholarly communication".<ref name="ORCID Announcement">{{cite web |title=RESEARCH STAKEHOLDERS ANNOUNCE COLLABORATION AMONG BROAD CROSS-SECTION OF COMMUNITY TO RESOLVE NAME AMBIGUITY IN SCHOLARLY RESEARCH|url=http://orcid.securesites.net:80/media/pdf/ORCID_Announcement.pdf |accessdate=19 June 2018 |via=internet archive |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100202055935/http://orcid.securesites.net:80/media/pdf/ORCID_Announcement.pdf |archivedate=2 February 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The "Open Researcher Contributor Identification Initiative" - hence the name ORCID - was created temporarily prior to incorporation.<ref name="Nature.ORCID_group">{{cite web |title=Welcome to the Open Researcher Contributor Identification Initiative (or ORCID) group on Nature Network |url=http://network.nature.com/groups/orcid/forum/topics/6533 |accessdate=1 June 2017 |via=internet archive |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130921060218/http://network.nature.com/groups/orcid/forum/topics/6533 |archivedate=21 September 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://support.orcid.org/knowledgebase/articles/115257-what-is-the-relationship-between-the-orcid-initiat|title=What is the relationship between the ORCID Initiative and ORCID, Inc.? – Feedback & support for ORCID|website=support.orcid.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-19}}</ref>
A prototype was developed on software adapted from that used by [[Thomson Reuters]] for its [[ResearcherID]] system.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://about.orcid.org/content/press-release-orcid-funding-and-development-efforts-target |title= Press Release: ORCID funding and development efforts on target| date=15 August 2011 |quote=ORCID also announced today that Thomson Reuters has provided ORCID with a perpetual license and royalty free use of ResearcherID code and intellectual property, giving ORCID the critical technology to create its system.}} {{Dead link|date=May 2014}}</ref> ORCID, Inc., was incorporated as an independent nonprofit organization incorporated in August 2010 in Delaware, United States of America, with an international board of directors.<ref name="Wiley12">{{cite web |title=Wiley-Blackwell Publishing News: An Update on the Open Researcher and Contributor Identifier (ORCID) |author=Craig Van Dyck |url=http://blogs.wiley.com/publishingnews/2012/08/28/an-update-on-the-open-researcher-and-contributor-identifier-orcid-2/ |accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="CoI">{{cite web|url=https://orcid.org/sites/default/files/orcidincde-certificateofincorporation-121130175812-phpapp01.pdf|title=Certificate of Incorporation of ORCID Inc.|date=5 August 2010|publisher=State of Delaware|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> Its executive Director, [[Laure Haak]], was appointed in April 2012.<ref name="Butler">{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/news/scientists-your-number-is-up-1.10740|title=Scientists: your number is up|last=Butler|first=Declan|date=30 May 2012|work=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|accessdate=31 May 2014}}</ref> From 2016, the board is chaired by [[Veronique Kiermer]] of [[PLOS]]<ref name="board">{{cite web|title=ORCID team|url=https://orcid.org/node/9#board|accessdate=1 November 2017|language=en|date=17 August 2012}}</ref> (the former chair was [[Ed Pentz]] of [[Crossref]]). ORCID is freely usable and [[interoperable]] with other ID systems.<ref name="Nature09"/> ORCID launched its registry services and started issuing user identifiers on 16 October 2012.<ref name="launchORCID"/> Formally, ORCID iDs are specified as URIs,<ref name="DG">{{cite web |url=http://orcid.org/trademark-and-id-display-guidelines |title=Trademark and iD Display Guidelines |publisher=ORCID |accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> for example, the ORCID iD for [[John Wilbanks]] is <nowiki>https://orcid.org/0000-0002-4510-0385</nowiki><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://support.orcid.org/knowledgebase/articles/116780-structure-of-the-orcid-identifier |title=Structure of the ORCID Identifier |publisher=ORCID}}</ref> (both https:// and http:// forms are supported; the former became canonical in November 2017<ref name="API2-1">{{cite web|last1=Meadows|first1=Alice|title=Announcing API 2.1 - ORCID iDs are now HTTPS!|url=https://orcid.org/blog/2017/11/16/announcing-api-21-orcid-ids-are-now-https|publisher=ORCID|accessdate=16 November 2017|language=en|date=15 November 2017}}</ref>). However, some publishers use the short form, e.g. "ORCID: 0000-0002-4510-0385"<ref name="Asakura" /><ref name="WP">{{cite web |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:ORCID |title=Template ORCID |work=[[Wikipedia]] |accessdate=16 February 2015}}</ref> (as a [[URN]]).
ORCID iDs are a subset of the [[International Standard Name Identifier]] (ISNI),<ref name="ISNI-ORCID">{{cite web|url=http://www.isni.org/isni_and_orcid |title=ISNI and ORCID |publisher=ISNI |accessdate=29 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130304210352/http://www.isni.org/isni_and_orcid |archivedate=March 4, 2013 }}</ref> under the auspices of the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (as ISO 27729), and the two organizations are cooperating. ISNI will uniquely identify contributors to [[book]]s, [[television programme]]s, and [[newspaper]]s, and has reserved a block of identifiers for use by ORCID,<ref name="ISNI-ORCID" /><ref name="ORCID.ISNI">{{cite web |url=http://about.orcid.org/content/what-relationship-between-isni-and-orcid |title=What is the relationship between ISNI and ORCID? |accessdate=23 October 2012}}</ref> in the range 0000-0001-5000-0007 to 0000-0003-5000-0001.<ref name="Structure">{{cite web|url=http://support.orcid.org/knowledgebase/articles/116780|title=Structure of the ORCID Identifier|publisher=ORCID|accessdate=23 July 2014}}</ref> It is therefore possible for a person to legitimately have both an ISNI and an ORCID iD<ref name="ISNI-AM">{{cite web |url=http://isni-url.oclc.nl/isni/0000000031979523 |title=ISNI 0000000031979523 |publisher=ISNI |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="ORCID-AM">{{cite web |url=http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5882-6823 |title=ORCID 0000-0001-5882-6823 |publisher=ORCID |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> – effectively, two ISNIs.
Both ORCID and ISNI use 16-character identifiers,<ref name="ORCID.ISNI" /> using the digits 0–9, and separated into groups of four by hyphens.<ref name="Asakura" /> The final character, which may also be a letter "X" representing the value "10" (for example, [[Nick Jennings (computer scientist)|Nick Jennings]]' ORCID iD is <nowiki>https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0166-248X</nowiki>,<ref name="Asakura" /><ref name="Jennings">{{cite web |url=https://orcid.org/0000-0003-0166-248X |title=Nick Jennings |publisher=ORCID |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> [[Stephen Hawking]]'s is <nowiki>https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9079-593X</nowiki><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://orcid.org/0000-0002-9079-593X|title=Stephen Hawking (0000-0002-9079-593X) - ORCID {{!}} Connecting Research and Researchers|last=ORCID|website=orcid.org|language=en|access-date=2017-10-23}}</ref>) is a MOD 11-2 [[check digit]] conforming to the [[ISO 7064|ISO/IEC 7064:2003]] standard.
An ORCID account for a fictitious person, [[Josiah Carberry]], exists as <nowiki>https://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097</nowiki>, for use in testing and as an example in documentation and training material.<ref name=orcid-carbery>{{cite web |title=Josiah Carberry |url=http://orcid.org/0000-0002-1825-0097 |publisher=ORCID, Inc |work=Biography |accessdate=22 December 2014|quote=Josiah Carberry is a fictitious person.}}</ref>
==Uses== The aim of ORCID is to aid "the transition from science to e-Science, wherein scholarly publications can be mined to spot links and ideas hidden in the ever-growing volume of scholarly literature".<ref>[http://about.orcid.org/about ORCID: About us].</ref> Another suggested use is to provide each researcher with "a constantly updated ‘digital curriculum vitae’ providing a picture of his or her contributions to science going far beyond the simple publication list".<ref name="Nature09"/> The idea is that other organizations will use the open-access ORCID database to build their own services.
It has been noted in an [[editorial]] in ''[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]'' that ORCID, in addition to tagging the contributions that scientists make to papers, "could also be assigned to data sets they helped to generate, comments on their colleagues’ blog posts or unpublished draft papers, edits of Wikipedia entries and much else besides".<ref name="Nature09"/>
In April 2014, ORCID announced plans to work with the [[Consortia Advancing Standards in Research Administration Information]] to record and acknowledge contributions to [[peer review]].<ref name="KSpeak">{{cite web |url=http://www.knowledgespeak.com/newsArchieveviewdtl.asp?pickUpBatch=2424 |title=Latest news on the stm publishing industry from scope e knowledge center pvt ltd |date=9 April 2014 |accessdate=15 April 2014}}</ref>
In an open letter dated 1 January 2016 eight publishers, including the [[Royal Society]], the [[American Geophysical Union]], [[Hindawi Publishing Corporation|Hindawi]], the [[Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers]], [[PLOS]], and [[Science (journal)|Science]], committed to requiring all authors in their journals to have an ORCID iD.<ref name="OpenLetter2016">{{cite web|url=https://orcid.org/content/requiring-orcid-publication-workflows-open-letter|title=Requiring ORCID in Publication Workflows: Open Letter|last=various|date=1 January 2016|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref><ref name="TSK-2016-01">{{cite web|url=http://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2016/01/07/why-some-publishers-are-requiring-orcid-ids-for-authors-an-interview-with-stuart-taylor-the-royal-society/|title=Why Some Publishers are Requiring ORCID iDs for Authors: An Interview with Stuart Taylor, The Royal Society|date=7 January 2016|work=[[The Scholarly Kitchen]]|accessdate=8 January 2016}}</ref>
== Members, sponsors and registrants == By the end of 2013 ORCID had 111 member organizations and over 460,000 registrants.<ref name="orcidEnd2013">{{cite web |url=http://orcid.org/blog/2014/01/03/orcid-2013-year-review |title=2013 Year in review |publisher=ORCID, Inc |accessdate=1 February 2014}}</ref><ref name="orcidmembers">{{cite web |url=http://orcid.org/about/community/members |title=Members |publisher=ORCID, Inc |accessdate=20 July 2013}}</ref><ref name="O'Beirne">{{cite web |url=http://www.oxfordjournals.com/for_societies/partner_newsletter_orchid.html |title=OUP and ORCID |last=O'Beirne |first=Richard |publisher=Oxford Journals |accessdate=15 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330144707/http://www.oxfordjournals.com/for_societies/partner_newsletter_orchid.html |archivedate=30 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> On 15 November 2014, ORCID announced the one-millionth registration.<ref name="1mTweet">{{cite web |url=https://mobile.twitter.com/ORCID_Org/status/533587481686704128 |title=Tweet |date=2014-11-15 |publisher=ORCID |accessdate=15 November 2014 |quote=It’s official! 1M of you have an ORCID iD! We thank the community, and look forward to continued collaboration.}}</ref> {{As of|2018|11|25}}, the number of registered accounts reported by ORCID was 5,641,303.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://orcid.org/statistics|title=ORCID|last=ORCID|website=orcid.org|language=en|access-date=25 November 2018}}</ref> The organizational members include many research institutions such as [[Caltech]] and [[Cornell University]], and publishers such as [[Elsevier]], [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]], [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]] and [[Nature Publishing Group]]. There are also commercial companies including [[Thomson Reuters]], academic societies and funding bodies.<ref name="ORCID.members">[http://about.orcid.org/about/community/sponsors ORCID Sponsors]</ref>
Grant-making bodies such as the Wellcome Trust (a charitable foundation) have also begun to mandate that applicants for funding provide an ORCID identifier.<ref name="Wilsdon">{{cite web|url=http://www.hefce.ac.uk/media/HEFCE,2014/Content/Pubs/Independentresearch/2015/The,Metric,Tide/2015_metric_tide.pdf|title=The Metric Tide|last=Wilsdon|date=July 2015|accessdate=10 July 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
=== National implementations ===
In several countries, consortia, including government bodies as partners, are operating at a national level to implement ORCID. For example, in Italy, seventy universities and four research centres are collaborating under the auspices of the {{ill|Conference of Italian University Rectors|it|Conferenza dei rettori delle università italiane}} (CRUI) and the [[National Agency for the Evaluation of the University and Research Institutes]] (ANVUR), in a project implemented by Cineca, a not-for-profit consortium representing the universities, research institutions, and the Ministry of Education.<ref name="Meadows">{{cite web|url=http://orcid.org/blog/2015/06/19/italy-launches-national-orcid-implementation|title=Italy Launches National ORCID Implementation |last=Meadows|first=Alice |publisher=ORCID |date=22 June 2015|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> In Australia, the government's [[National Health and Medical Research Council]] (NHMRC) and [[Australian Research Council]] (ARC) "encourage all researchers applying for funding to have an ORCID identifier".<ref name="NHMRC">{{cite web|url=https://www.nhmrc.gov.au/grants-funding/policy/nhmrc-and-arc-statement-open-researcher-and-contributor-id-orcid|title=NHMRC and ARC Statement on Open Researcher and Contributor ID (ORCID)|date=10 April 2015|publisher=National Health and Medical Research Council|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> The French scientific article repository [[Hyper_Articles_en_Ligne|HAL]] is also inviting its users to enter their ORCID number.<ref name="HAL">{{cite web|url=https://doc.archives-ouvertes.fr/identifiant-auteur-idhal-cv/|title=Identifiant auteur IdHAL et CV|date=1 June 2018}}</ref>
== Integrations == [[File:2014-05-13 Nick Jennings ORCID Wikidata screenshot.png|thumb|Nick Jennings' ORCID in his Wikidata entry]]
In addition to members and sponsors, journals, publishers, and other services have included ORCID in their workflows or databases. For example, the ''[[Journal of Neuroscience]]'',<ref name="JoN">{{cite web |url=http://www.jneurosci.org/site/misc/announcementspage.xhtml |title=Announcements |date=April 2014 |publisher=Journal of Neuroscience |accessdate=20 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140622104524/http://www.jneurosci.org/site/misc/announcementspage.xhtml |archivedate=22 June 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="SfNeuroscience">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfn.org/news-and-calendar/news-and-calendar/news/spotlight/2014/the-journal-of-neuroscience-rolls-out-orcid-integration |title=The Journal of Neuroscience Rolls Out ORCID Integration |publisher=Society for Neuroscience |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> [[Springer Publishing]],<ref name="SpringerPub">{{cite web |url=https://www.springer.com/authors/author+zone?SGWID=0-168002-12-1028464-0 |title=Author Zone 16 - ORCID |publisher=[[Springer Publishing]] |accessdate=21 April 2014}}</ref> the [[Hindawi Publishing Corporation]],<ref name="Asakura">{{cite web |url=http://www.hindawi.com/80647648/ |title=Hiroshi Asakura |publisher=[[Hindawi Publishing Corporation]] |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> [[Europe PubMed Central|Europe PMC]],<ref name="EPMC">{{cite web |url=http://europepmc.org/orcid/import |title=ORCID Article Claiming |publisher=Europe PubMed Central |accessdate=16 May 2014}}</ref> the Japanese [[National Institute of Informatics]]'s Researcher Name Resolver,<ref name="Resolver">{{cite web |url=http://rns.nii.ac.jp/html_us/orcid_integration_help_en.html |title=ORCID integration |work=Researcher Name Resolver |publisher=[[National Institute of Informatics]] |accessdate=20 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140421064132/http://rns.nii.ac.jp/html_us/orcid_integration_help_en.html |archivedate=21 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Wikipedia]],<ref name="Wikipedia">{{cite web |url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Wikipedia_articles_with_ORCID_identifiers |title=Category:Wikipedia articles with ORCID identifiers |last=Wikipedia authors |work=[[Wikipedia]] |publisher=[[Wikimedia Foundation]] |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref> and [[Wikidata]].<ref name="Wikidata">{{cite web |url=https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Special:WhatLinksHere/Property:P496 |title=Pages that link to "Property:P496" |last=Wikidata contributors |work=Wikidata |publisher=[[Wikimedia Foundation]] |accessdate=20 April 2014}}</ref>
Some online services have created tools for exporting data to, or importing data from, ORCID. These include [[Scopus]],<ref name="Scopus">{{cite web |url=http://orcid.scopusfeedback.com |title=Scopus2Orcid - Use the Scopus to Orcid Author details and documents wizard to collect all your Scopus records in one unique author profile |publisher=[[Scopus]] |accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> [[Figshare]],<ref name="Figshare">{{cite web |url=http://figshare.com/blog/figshare_ORCID_integration/86 |title=figshare ORCID integration |publisher=[[Figshare]] |accessdate=7 May 2014}}</ref> Thomson Reuters' [[ResearcherID]] system,<ref name="ResearcherID">{{cite web |url=http://wokinfo.com/researcherid/integration/ |title=RID - ORCID Integration - IP & Science |publisher=Thomson Reuters |accessdate=29 March 2013}}</ref> [[Researchfish]],<ref name="Researchfish">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchfish.com/node/2525|title=Researchfish now integrating with the ORCID registry|date=4 July 2015|publisher=Researchfish|accessdate=14 July 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150715022313/https://www.researchfish.com/node/2525|archivedate=15 July 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> the [[British Library]] (for their [[EThOS]] thesis catalogue),<ref name="EThOS">{{cite web|url=http://ethos.bl.uk/About.do|title=British Library EThOS - about searching and ordering theses online|work=[[British Library]]|accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref> [[ProQuest]] (for their [[ProQuest Dissertations and Theses]] service),<ref name="ProQuest">{{cite web|url=http://www.proquest.com/blog/pqblog/2015/Connected-from-the-Beginning-Adding-ORCID-to-ETDs.html|title=Connected from the Beginning: Adding ORCID to ETDs|date=12 October 2015|publisher=ProQuest|accessdate=15 October 2015}}</ref> and [[Frontiers Media#Loop|Frontiers Loop]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ponto|first1=Michelle|title=ORCID and Loop: A New Researcher Profile System Integration|url=https://orcid.org/blog/2015/10/07/orcid-and-loop-new-researcher-profile-system-integration|website=ORCID|accessdate=7 September 2016|date=7 October 2015}}</ref>
In October 2015, [[DataCite]], [[Crossref]] and ORCID announced that the former organisations would update ORCID records, "when an ORCID identifier is found in newly registered DOI names".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.datacite.org/explaining-the-datacite-orcid-auto-update/ |title=Explaining the DataCite/ORCID Auto-update |publisher=[[DataCite]] |date=29 October 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://crosstech.crossref.org/2015/10/auto-update-has-arrived-orcid-records-move-to-the-next-level.html |title=Auto-Update Has Arrived! ORCID Records Move to the Next Level |publisher=[[Crossref]] |date=26 October 2015 }}</ref>
Third-party tools allow the migration of content from other services into ORCID, for example Mendeley2ORCID, for [[Mendeley]].
Some ORCID data may also be retrieved as [[RDF/XML]], [[Turtle (syntax)|RDF Turtle]], [[XML]] or [[JSON]].<ref name="QD">{{cite web |url=http://graphite.ecs.soton.ac.uk/browser/?uri=http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5882-6823 |title=Q&D RDF Browser |accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.w3.org/2015/03/orcid-semantics |title=Proposal for the Improvement of the Semantics of ORCIDs |first=Phil |last=Archer |publisher=W3C |accessdate=19 April 2015 }}</ref> ORCID uses [[GitHub]] as its code repository.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://github.com/ORCID |title=ORCID, Inc |accessdate=19 April 2015 }}</ref>
== See also == <!-- New links in alphabetical order please --> * [[Authority control]] * [[Digital Author Identifier]] (DAI) * [[OpenID]] * [[ResearcherID]] * [[Ringgold identifier]] (RIN) * [[Virtual International Authority File]] (VIAF)
{{Wikidata property |1=P496}}

== External link == * [https://orcid.org/ Website of ORCID]

{{italic title}} [[Image:Fiskebåt i Simrishamn.jpg|100px|thumb|Fishing boat]] '''''One Fish, Two Fish, Crawfish, Bluefish: The Smithsonian Sustainable Seafood Cookbook''''' ({{ISBN|1-58834-169-0}}) is a collection of [[seafood]] recipes specifically chosen for their environmental [[sustainability]]. It was [[Author|written]] by Carole C. Baldwin and Julie H. Mounts, illustrated by Charlotte Knox, and [[Publishing|published]] in October 2003 by [[Smithsonian Institution Press]].
The title of the book is itself a reference to ''[[One Fish Two Fish Red Fish Blue Fish]]'', a popular children's book by [[Dr. Seuss]].
== References == * ({{ISBN|1-58834-169-0}})
== External links == *[http://www.mnh.si.edu/seafood/ Smithsonian Seafood Website]

{{Infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Oxford Latin Dictionary | title_orig = | translator = | image = Oxford Latin Dictionary.jpg| caption = | author = P.G.W. Glare | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | release_date = 1968 to 1982; reprinted with corrections 1996; 2nd edition 2012 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]]) | pages = 2,400 | isbn = 978-0-19-958031-6 | dewey= 473/.21 19 | congress= PA2365 .E5 O9 2012 | oclc= 785944255 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }}
The '''''Oxford Latin Dictionary''''' (or '''OLD''') is the standard English lexicon of [[Classical Latin]], compiled from sources written before AD 200. Begun in 1933, it was published in [[Fascicle (book)|fascicles]] between 1968 and 1982; a lightly revised second edition was released in 2012.
The dictionary was created in order to meet the need for a more modern Latin-English dictionary than [[A Latin Dictionary|Lewis & Short's ''Latin Dictionary'']], while being less ambitious in scope than the unfinished ''[[Thesaurus Linguae Latinae]]''. It was based on a new reading of classical sources, based on the advances in lexicography in creating the [[Oxford English Dictionary]].<ref>{{Cite web | last = Stray | first = Christopher | title = The bizarre history of the Oxford Latin Dictionary | work = OUPblog | accessdate = 2013-10-19 | date = 2012-05-03 | url = http://blog.oup.com/2012/05/bizarre-history-oxford-latin-dictionary/ }}</ref>
== History == Although Lewis and Short's ''Latin Dictionary'' was widely used in the English world by the end of the nineteenth century, its faults were widely felt among classicists.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/287803 | issn = 0002-9475 | volume = 20 | issue = 2 | pages = 169–85 | last = Leeper | first = Alexander | title = Notes on Lewis and Short's Latin-English Lexicon | journal = The American Journal of Philology | year = 1899 | jstor = 287803 }}</ref> While Oxford University Press had attempted the creation of a new Latin dictionary as early as 1875, these projects failed. The OLD was spurred by the submission of a report in 1924 by [[Alexander Souter]] on the deficiencies of Lewis and Short; he eventually became the dictionary's first editor. The compilation of the more than one million quotations on which the work was based began in 1933. After Souter's retirement in 1939, [[Cyril Bailey]] and [[J.M. Wyllie]] were appointed co-editors. From 1949, Wyllie was the sole editor, and he was replaced, following tensions among the editorial staff, in 1954 by [[P.G.W. Glare]], who remained in the position until the completion of the lexicon.<ref>{{Cite book | edition = 2 | publisher = Oxford University Press | isbn = 9780199580316 | pages = xi–xvii | editors = P.G.W. Glare (ed.) | last = Stray | first = Christopher | title = Oxford Latin dictionary | chapter = The Oxford Latin Dictionary: A Historical Introduction | location = Oxford | year = 2012 | url = http://www.oupjapan.co.jp/upload/samples/9780199580316_Introduction.pdf }}</ref> The dictionary was originally published in eight fascicles at two-yearly intervals from 1968 until 1982. The complete dictionary contains c. 40,000 entries (covering 100,000 senses). It was generally well received by classicists.<ref>{{Cite journal | issn = 0017-3835 | volume = 15 | issue = 2 | pages = 127–129 | last = Barrow | first = R. H. | title = The 'Oxford Latin Dictionary' | journal = Greece & Rome | date = October 1968 | jstor = 642423 | doi=10.1017/s0017383500017472 }} {{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/294632 | issn = 0002-9475 | volume = 105 | issue = 1 | pages = 91–100 | last = Luck | first = Georg | title = Review of Oxford Latin Dictionary by P.G.W. Glare | journal = The American Journal of Philology | date = Spring 1984 | jstor = 294632 }}</ref>
Other members of the editorial staff included [[Charles Oscar Brink|C.O. Brink]] (1938–42), E.A. Parker (1939–46), [[Margaret Alford|M. Alford]] (1942–45), [[John Chadwick|J. Chadwick]] (1946–52), B.V. Slater (1947–49), [[David Clayton Browning|D.C. Browning]] (1949–50), W.M. Edwards (1950–69), [[J.D. Craig]] (1952–53), C.L. Howard (1952–58), [[Godfrey Edmund Turton|G.E. Turton]] (1954–70), [[Reginald Haynes Barrow|R.H. Barrow]] (1954–82), [[Sophie Trenkner|S. Trenkner]] (1955–57), R.C. Palmer (1957–82), G.M. Lee (1968–82), and [[David Sebastian Raven|D. Raven]] (1969–70).
In 2012, a second edition of the dictionary was published in two volumes (the binding of the 1982 single-volume edition has a tendency to fall apart under the paper's weight), removes some English translations now considered to be archaic, and presents the material in a clearer fashion using the [[Arno (typeface)|Arno]] typeface.
== Comparison with other dictionaries == Although the OLD was intended as a replacement for Lewis and Short’s dictionary from 1879, its lack of information about Latin writings from after AD 200 has drawn criticism from its users.<ref>{{Cite book | publisher = Duckworth | isbn = 9780715639160 | pages = 139–76 | editors = Christopher Stray (ed.) | last = Henderson | first = John | title = Classical dictionaries: past, present and future | chapter = A1–ZYTHUM: DOMIMINA NUSTIO ILLUMEA, or Out with the OLD (1931–82) | location = London | year = 2010 }}</ref> Lewis and Short's coverage of late and ecclesiastical Latin (if inconsistent), combined with the fact that this dictionary is freely available online, has meant that it has remained in continuous use.
The ''[[Thesaurus Linguae Latinae]]'' is far more ambitious than the OLD, but after more than 100 years only two thirds of this comprehensive dictionary has been published.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1353/apa.2008.0006 | issn = 1533-0699 | volume = 137 | issue = 2 | pages = 483–90 | last = Hays | first = Gregory | title = Latin from A to P: The TLL in the 20th Century | journal = Transactions of the American Philological Association | accessdate = 2013-10-19 | year = 2007 | url = http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/transactions_of_the_american_philological_association/v137/137.2hays.html }}</ref>
==See also== *[[A Latin Dictionary]] *[[Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources]] *[[William Whitaker's Words]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.oxfordscholarlyeditions.com/page/the-oxford-latin-dictionary Oxford Scholarly Editions Online] {{Authority control}} [[Category:1982 books]] [[Category:Oxford dictionaries|Latin Dictionary, Oxford]] [[Category:Latin dictionaries]] [[Category:20th-century Latin books]]

{{italic title}} {{Contains Tangut text}} [[File:Pearl in Palm page 14b.png|thumb|220px|Page from the ''Pearl in the Palm'' found at the Northern [[Mogao Caves]]]] The '''''Pearl in the Palm''''' or the '''''Timely Pearl''''' ([[Tangut script|Tangut]]: {{Tangut|𗼇𘂜𗟲𗿳𗖵𘃎𘇂𗊏|L2344 L5882 L1014 L3589 L0433 L5370 L1136 L2583}}; {{zh|c=番漢合時掌中珠|p=Fān-Hàn Héshí Zhǎngzhōngzhū}}) is a bilingual glossary between the [[Chinese language|Chinese]] and [[Tangut language|Tangut]] languages. It survives as a single complete copy of a 12th-century woodblock printed book that was discovered in the [[Tangut people|Tangut]] city of [[Kharakhoto]]. In addition, a single page from a different copy of the same edition of the ''Pearl in the Palm'' was found at the Northern [[Mogao Caves]] in 1989.<ref>{{Cite web | title=敦煌研究院藏国家珍贵古籍介绍(三) | url=http://www.dha.ac.cn/03F9/index.htm | publisher=[[Dunhuang Academy]] | date=2011-01-05 | accessdate=2013-04-06 }}</ref> The book transcribes the pronunciation of Chinese words into Tangut characters, and the pronunciation of Tangut characters into Chinese characters, and so is a very important source for Tangut historical [[phonology]], and was the primary source before the publication of monolingual Tangut dictionaries.
==Discovery== In 1909, the Russian explorer [[Pyotr Kozlov]] unearthed a number of texts and artefacts in [[Ejin Banner]], Inner Mongolia, including the ''Pearl in the Palm'' and transported them back to [[St. Petersburg]], Russia. There, [[Aleksei Ivanovich Ivanov]], professor at [[Saint Petersburg State University]], who was aware of its value, added them to his collection. It is now in the collection of the [[Institute of Oriental Manuscripts of the Russian Academy of Sciences]] in Saint Petersburg.
In 1912, Chinese scholars [[Luo Zhenyu]] and [[Feng Ge]] visited Ivanov upon learning about the work in his possession, and were given access to nine pages, which they photocopied for study. In 1922 Luo Zhenyu met Ivanov again, in Tianjin. It was only then he would only have access to the full text, then ordered his son to make a full copy.
The Belgian scholar [[Luc Kwanten]] visit to the Soviet Union in the late 1970s, and was able to photograph the whole of "The Pearl in the Palm". In 1982, the book finally saw the light of day when the photographed version was published in the United States.
==Content and style==
The original book consists of 37 [[xylograph]] folios in [[concertina]] format. The preface is identical content written in both Chinese and Tangut. From the sentence "How can you mix with foreigners without learning foreign words, How can you be counted amongst the Han without learning Han words" (不學番言，則豈和番人之眾；不會漢語，則豈入漢人之數) it is clear that the book aimed to facilitate the Tanguts and the Chinese to learn each other's languages.
The book contains words 414 CPC{{Clarify|date=September 2011}}, according to three powers are divided into nine categories: celestial bodies, celestial images, sky changes, terrestrial bodies, terrestrial images, terrestrial use, human body, human phase, human matters. One category is the most extensive content: personnel issues accounts for half of all the content.
Each entry contains four elements: from right to left, Tangut phonetics in Chinese, Tangut script, Chinese script, and Chinese phonetics in Tangut. The book is important in understanding and interpretation of the now dead Tangut language.
==Notes== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Dictionaries of Chinese}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pearl In The Palm}} [[Category:Tangut texts]] [[Category:Chinese dictionaries]] [[Category:Institute of Oriental Manuscripts of the Russian Academy of Sciences]]

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{lang|de|Schwules Museum|nocat=y}}}} The '''{{lang|de|Schwules Museum*}}''' ('''Gay Museum*''') is a museum exhibiting [[LGBT culture|LGBT life]] in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]], which opened in 1985. [[File:Schwules Museum* Berlin.JPG|thumb|{{lang|de|Schwules Museum*}} House]]
==History and mission== The impetus for the founding of the {{lang|de|Schwules Museum*}} was a successful exhibition on [[gay]] topics at the Berlin Museum ({{lang|de|[[Märkisches Museum]]}}) in summer 1984, called ''Eldorado''. It was the first public exposition in Germany of recent research on gay life. In 1985 the organisation {{lang|de|Verein der Freunde eines Schwulen Museums in Berlin e.V.}} was founded and opened its own museum dedicated exclusively to LGBT topics at {{lang|de|[[Mehringdamm]] 61}} in the district of {{lang|de|[[Kreuzberg]]}}.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://bewegung.taz.de/organisationen/schwulesmuseum |title=Schwules Museum - Freunde eines Schwulen Museums e.V. |work=[[Die Tageszeitung]] |language=de }}</ref> The museum was located above a gay nightclub.
From December 2004 to May 2013, there was a permanent exhibition called {{lang|de|Selbstbewusstsein und Beharrlichkeit. 200 Jahre schwule Geschichte}} ("Self-Awareness and Endurance: 200 Years of Gay History"). It depicted the strategies, options and problems of gay people in seeking to live a self-determined life, find others and organise networks in the period from 1790 to 1990. In association with this theme, the social and legal background was presented, such as the anti-gay [[Paragraph 175]] of the German penal code; the associated marginalisation, persecution and [[criminalisation of homosexuality]]; as well as the successes of the [[LGBT social movements|gay rights movement]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gay-web.de/kultur/schwulesmuseum.html |title=Selbstbewusstsein und Beharrlichkeit — 200 Jahre schwule Geschichte: Die ständige Ausstellung des Schwulen Museums |work=gay-web.de |language=de |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090421003555/http://www.gay-web.de/kultur/schwulesmuseum.html |archivedate=2009-04-21 |df= }}</ref> At the moment the permanent exhibition is not displaced, but it is planned to open again in 2016.{{update inline |date=November 2017 }}
==Location== [[File:Schwules Museum* Shop.JPG|thumb|Museums shop in the {{lang|de|Schwules Museum*}}, 2015]] [[File:Schwules Museum* Café.JPG|thumb|Café in the {{lang|de|Schwulen Museum*}}, 2015]] In the summer of 2013, it moved to a former printing house in {{lang|de|Lützowstraße 73}}, more than doubling its exhibition space,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.spiegel.de/kultur/gesellschaft/neueroeffnung-schwules-museum-berlin-a-911225.html |title=Zarte Fußballer und Frauen mit Bart |trans-title=Tender footballers and women with beards |author=Ingeborg Wiensowski |work=[[Der Spiegel]] |date=16 July 2013 |language=de }}</ref> and is the world's first gay museum.<ref>{{cite news |author=Sara Richards |url=https://www.npr.org/blogs/nprberlinblog/2010/02/schwules_museum.html |title=Berlin's Schwules Museum, Exploring The Past And Present |work=[[NPR]] blogs |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=3 April 2010 }}</ref>
The museum shows several temporary exhibitions every year. These include historical exhibitions illuminating particular periods or historical developments, such as ''Goodbye to Berlin. {{lang|de|100 Jahre Schwulenbewegung}}'' ("Goodbye to Berlin: 100 Years of the Gay Rights Movement", 1997). The exhibition {{lang|de|Verfolgung homosexueller Männer in Berlin 1933–45}} ("Persecution of Homosexual Men in Berlin 1933–45"), in collaboration with the [[Sachsenhausen concentration camp#The Sachsenhausen camp today|{{lang|de|Sachsenhausen|nocat=y}} Memorial]], dealt with the [[persecution of homosexuals in Nazi Germany and the Holocaust|experience of gays in the Nazi era]].
The museum also holds series of exhibitions on individuals, groups and organisations, such as {{lang|de|[[Der Kreis]]}} ("The Circle") and {{lang|de|Gesellschaft für Reform des Sexualrechts}} ("Society for the Reform of Sexual Law"). A continuing series of homages to gay people in public life has included [[Oscar Wilde]], [[Marlene Dietrich]], {{lang|fr|[[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]]}}, {{lang|fr|[[Michel Foucault]]}} and [[Thomas Mann]].
Through the second half of 2015, {{lang|de|Schwules Museum*}} and the German Historical Museum presented the exhibition {{lang|de|Homosexualität_en}} ("Homosexuality_ies"), jointly funded by the {{ill|German Federal Cultural Foundation|de|Kulturstiftung des Bundes}} and the {{ill|Cultural Foundation of the German states|de|Kulturstiftung der Länder}} and displaying a great range on the history, politics and culture of homosexuality.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.dhm.de/en/ausstellungen/archive/2015/homosexuality-ies.html |title=Homosexuality_ies |publisher=[[Deutsches Historisches Museum]] |date=2015 |accessdate=12 November 2017 }}</ref>
The museum archive houses periodicals going back to 1896 and a collection of photographs, videos, films, sound recordings, autographs, art works, and ephemera. The library currently contains approximately 10,000 books on homosexuality.
In December 2009, the museum received its first allocation of public money, a two-year grant from the cultural funds of the [[Berlin Senate]], and declared that this would make possible a planned broadening of its focus to encompass other alternative [[sexual identities]] other than [[male homosexuality]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.siegessaeule.de/news/senatsgeld-fuer-das-schwule-museum.html |title=Senatsgeld für das Schwule Museum |trans-title=Public funds for the {{lang|de|Schwule Museum}} |work=Siegessäule |date=15 December 2009 |accessdate=3 April 2010 |language=de }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lesbian.or.at/news/1260533540 |title=Das Schwule Museum in Berlin erhält Senatsförderung |trans-title=The Gay Museum in Berlin receives Senate funding |publisher=rainbow.at |date=11 December 2009 |accessdate=3 April 2010 |language=de }}</ref> above all a further emphasis on [[lesbian]] and [[transgender]] people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lesben.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6064:berlin-das-schwule-museum-wird-immer-lesbischer&catid=130:historisches&Itemid=132 |title=Berlin: Das Schwule Museum wird immer lesbischer |trans-title=Berlin: The Gay Museum is becoming more and more lesbian |publisher=lesben.org |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=3 April 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100620185458/http://lesben.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=6064:berlin-das-schwule-museum-wird-immer-lesbischer&catid=130:historisches&Itemid=132 |archivedate=20 June 2010 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== * {{lang|de|[[Centrum Schwule Geschichte]]}} (Cologne) * [[GLBT Historical Society]] (San Francisco) * [[ONE National Gay & Lesbian Archives]] (Los Angeles)
==References== ===Bibliography=== * Michael Bollé, ed. {{lang|de|Eldorado: Homosexuelle Frauen und Männer in Berlin, 1850–1950; Geschichte, Alltag und Kultur. Berlin: Frölich und Kaufmann, 1984.}} {{ISBN|3-88725-068-0}}. 2nd ed. {{lang|de|Berlin: Verein der Freunde eines Schwulen Museums in Berlin e.V.}}, 1992. {{ISBN|3-89468-032-6}}. ===Notes=== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website}} * [http://berlinstories.org/2010/02/14/geoffrey-upton/ Geoffrey Upton on the Gay Museum], ''Berlin Stories'', 14 February 2010 (audio)
{{coord|52|29|27|N|13|23|16|E|region:DE-BE_type:landmark_source:dewiki|display=title}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:LGBT history in Germany]] [[Category:LGBT museums and archives]] [[Category:Museums in Berlin]] [[Category:LGBT organisations in Germany]]

[[Image:Settlers House and Barn, Shelburne Museum, Shelburne VT.jpg|thumb|right|250px|<center>Settlers House and Barn</center>]] '''Settlers' House''' was built in 1845 in [[East Charlotte, Vermont]]. The house is set up at the [[Shelburne Museum]] to show visitors life in the 18th century. The [[barn]] situated next to the house was built as a working demonstration in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-03-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315094815/http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/ |archive-date=2009-03-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==History== French Canadian lumberjacks probably built the '''Settlers’ Cabin''' in [[East Charlotte, Vermont]] in about 1800. Constructed of hand-hewn and [[dovetail]]ed beech and pine timbers, Settlers’ Cabin is typical of the type of structure that Vermont settlers, loggers, and trappers often built as temporary homes.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/buildings_and_grounds/detail.php?id=25 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204192743/http://shelburnemuseum.org/buildings_and_grounds/detail.php?id=25 |archivedate=2009-02-04 |df= }}</ref>
When the [[Shelburne Museum]] acquired the structure in 1955, [[clapboard (architecture)]] facing obscured the log structure beneath. After moving the building’s exterior walls to the grounds intact, the Museum provided a new foundation, replaced the roof, and restored the cabin’s single interior room, stone fireplace, and sleeping loft. The structure, in combination with the adjacent hay barn, which the Museum constructed in 2001, now houses the Museum’s only living exhibition that reveals how early Vermont settlers lived.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/buildings_and_grounds/detail.php?id=25 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204192743/http://shelburnemuseum.org/buildings_and_grounds/detail.php?id=25 |archivedate=2009-02-04 |df= }}</ref>
In 1959 the Museum constructed the [[sawmill]] adjacent to Settlers’ Cabin. In colonial America wood was needed to construct everything from sailing ships to storage kegs and lumber, forested by loggers like the French Canadians who built Settlers’ Cabin, quickly emerged as the most important cash crop of 18th-century America. The Museum’s Sawmill illustrates how this [[cash crop]] was prepared for market.<ref>Shelburne Museum. 1993. Shelburne Museum: A Guide to the Collections. Shelburne: Shelburne Museum, Inc.</ref>
Swiftly moving water can create energy powerful enough to run machinery. While in operation, the water’s motion forced the sawmill’s saw blade up and down, enabling it to cut through logs directed into its path. At full speed, the saw cut two strokes per second, which allowed a sawyer to cut a ten-foot board in eight minutes.<ref>Shelburne Museum. 1993. Shelburne Museum: A Guide to the Collections. Shelburne: Shelburne Museum, Inc.</ref>
Historically the term “sawmill” referred both to the mill building and to the machinery it contained. Shelburne’s Sawmill was built to house equipment from a [[South Royalton, Vermont]] sawmill that was operated by Jeremiah Trescott and his partner Captain Stevens from the late 18th century. The Shepard family, descendants of Trescott, continued to operate the mill until the early 20th century and later donated its contents to the Museum.<ref>Lovejoy, Mary Evelyn Wood.History of Royalton, Vermont.</ref>
==See also== *[[Settler]] *[[Logging]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.shelburnemuseum.org/ Shelburne Museum website]
{{coord|44|22|34.69|N|73|13|46.89|W|region:US|display=title}}

{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Stele.JPG | painting_alignment = Front | image_size = 300px | title = Stele II | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Ellsworth Kelly | year = 1973 | type = sculpture | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = 10 | height_inch = 6 | width_imperial = 9 | width_inch = 10 | length_imperial = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = Washington, D.C. | museum = [[National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden]] | coordinates = {{coord|38|53|29.51|N|77|1|20.42|W|type:landmark_region:US_dim:3}} | owner = National Gallery of Art }} '''''Stele II''''' is an abstract sculpture, constructed in 1973, by [[Ellsworth Kelly]].<ref>[http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?&profile=all&source=~!siartinventories&uri=full=3100001~!338956~!0#focus "''Stele II'', (sculpture)"], ''SIRIS''.</ref>

[[Image:Brittoncottage.jpg|thumb|Britton Cottage]][[Image:Brittoninside.jpg|thumb|Britton Cottage]][[Image:The Cubberly-Britton House.jpg|thumb|The Britton Cottage in 1920]] The '''Britton Cottage''', formerly known as the Cubberly House<ref>{{cite book |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= 1915 |title= Proceedings - Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=KLZLAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA187&dq=britton+cottage+staten+island&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiB2rCv5rbUAhWn64MKHcgpD18Q6AEILjAC#v=onepage&q=britton%20cottage%20staten%20island&f=false |location= New York |publisher= The New Era Printing Company |access-date= 2017-06-11}}</ref>, is a house in the [[Historic Richmond Town]] museum complex in the neighborhood of [[Richmondtown]], [[Staten Island]], in [[New York City]]. The oldest section of the cottage dates to 1671, with additions in the mid-18th century. It is constructed of stone and timberframe components. The house was originally located at the intersection of New Dorp Lane and Cedar Grove Avenue in the [[New Dorp Beach]] section of Staten Island,<ref name = "ref1">{{cite web|title=Postcard, "The Old Britton House"|url=https://statenisland.pastperfectonline.com/photo/89596DCA-B38A-4D2D-967B-243647013968|website=Staten Island Historical Society Online Collections Database|publisher=Historic Richmond Town|accessdate=20 April 2017}}</ref> but was moved to its current location in 1967 when it was threatened with demolition.
==History of ownership== The earliest section of the house was built to serve court and government functions. One of its earliest known inhabitants was town clerk and justice of the peace Obadiah Holmes, the son of early Rhode Island settler [[Obadiah Holmes]], who came from Long Island. In 1679, he transferred ownership of the property to his son Obadiah. Nathaniel Britton, an ancestor of the man for whom the cottage is named, acquired the house in 1695. Isaac Cubberly bought the house in 1761 and the house remained in his family for eighty-six years. [[Nathaniel Lord Britton|Dr. Nathaniel Lord Britton]], a botanist and the creator of the [[New York Botanical Garden]], became the owner of the house in the 19th century and deeded the house to the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences in 1915.
==See also== *[[List of the oldest buildings in New York]] *[[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Staten Island]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Richmond County, New York]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== Other sources == *Sterling, Keir B. 1997. ''Biographical Dictionary of American and Canadian Naturalists and Environmentalists,'' Westport, Conn: Greenwood Press. *[http://www.neighborhoodpreservationcenter.org/db/bb_files/76CUBBERLY-BRITTON.pdf Neighborhood Preservation center, New York, NY]
==External links== * [https://www.historicrichmondtown.org/17-treasures/sites-structures/69-britton-cottege, Britton Cottage on the Historic Richmond Town website]

{{italic title}} {{short description|19th/20th/21st-century series of critical editions of Shakespeare's works}} '''''The Cambridge Shakespeare''''' is a long-running series of [[critical editions]] of [[William Shakespeare]]'s works published by [[Cambridge University Press]]. The name encompasses three distinct series: ''The Cambridge Shakespeare'' (1863–1866), ''The New Shakespeare'' (1921–1969), and ''The New Cambridge Shakespeare'' (1984–).
==The Cambridge Shakespeare (1863–1866)== [[File:The Works of William Shakespeare, Vol. 1 (1863) - title page.jpg|thumb|The title page of ''The Works of William Shakespeare'', Vol. 1 (1863) edited by William George Clark and John Glover.]] ''The Cambridge Shakespeare'' was edited by [[William George Clark]] and [[William Aldis Wright]] and released in nine volumes between 1863 and 1866. Clark and Wright used the ''[[First Folio]]'' (1623) as their base text and collated it with the second, third, and fourth folios as well as all the known quarto editions. The edition modernized the orthography to 19th-century standards rather than preserve the variable [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] spelling, but generally left the grammar and metre unchanged.
In the edition, each page of a play contains a critical apparatus at the end. Where the folio text differs markedly from the quarto editions the quarto text is included in small type after the main text. Notes on variants, emendations, or pointing out or clarifying passages of particular difficulty or interest are placed at the end of each play.
In what a modern editor called "a bold move for a Victorian edition", Clark and Wright restored various original phrases that had previousøly been considered profane, where needed to preserve metre or meaning.
In 2009, [[Cambridge University Press]] reissued all nine volumes as part of their ''Cambridge Library Collection'' which aims to preserve access to "books of enduring scholarly value". The reissued editions are:

|editor1-first = William George |editor1-link = William George Clark |editor2-last = Wright |editor2-first = William Aldis |editor2-link = William Aldis Wright |volume = 9 |publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] |location = Cambridge |year = 2009 |orig-year = first published 1866 |isbn = 9780511701276 |doi = 10.1017/CBO9780511701276 |ref = none }} {{refend}}
==The New Shakespeare (1921–1969)== ''The New Shakespeare'' was published between 1921 and 1969.<ref name=NewCambridge>Publication preface to The New Cambridge Shakespeare, ''Henry VIII'', by Philip Brockbank, 1990</ref> The series was edited by [[Arthur Quiller-Couch]] and [[J. Dover Wilson]].<ref name=NewCambridge/>
The earlier volumes of the series contain critical introductions by Quiller-Couch (signed "Q") and written in a ''[[belles lettres]]'' style that, according to R. A. Foakes in ''The Oxford Handbook to Shakespeare'' (2003), have been "largely forgotten". The textual work by Wilson, however, "proved enormously influential."
In the 1921 edition of ''[[The Tempest]]'', Wilson included a [[facsimile]] of the [[manuscript]] for ''[[Sir Thomas More (play)|Sir Thomas More]]'' and a full discussion of the copy for the texts, which afterward became required reading in the field. Shakespeare's hand in the manuscript for ''Sir Thomas More'' was discovered by [[Edward Maunde Thompson]] in ''Shakespeare's Handwriting: A Study'' (1916)—and treated in detail in what is still the definitive study: ''Shakespeare's Hand in the Play of Sir Thomas More'' (1923) by [[Alfred W. Pollard]], [[W. W. Greg]], [[R. W. Chambers]] and Wilson—but ''The New Shakespeare'' was the first series of editions to bring this discovery to bear on editing Shakespeare. The series was also the first to apply Pollard's recognition of the primacy of the quartos to textual work.
The last volume of the series was ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]'', edited by J. C. Maxwell in 1969.<ref>Prefatory note, ''Henry VIII'', The New Shakespeare, 1969</ref>
==The New Cambridge Shakespeare (1984–)== [[Image:NewCambridgeShakespeare.jpg|thumb|right|The cover of a New Cambridge Shakespeare edition]] ''The New Cambridge Shakespeare'' began in 1984, and several editions were published each year, so that today, all of Shakespeare's plays and poems are available in the series. The series was designed to replace ''The New Shakespeare'' series.
The New Cambridge editions feature lengthy introductions and copious annotation. They are distinctive in appearance, being taller in shape than most of their competitors. The earliest editions featured cyan covers with an illustration by C. Walter Hodges of the relevant play in performance on an Elizabethan stage. In the 1990s, these covers were replaced with a new uniform blue design featuring a multicoloured sketch of Shakespeare's face based on a drawing by [[David Hockney]]. In the 2000s, the series was reissued again with each play receiving a specific photographic image (in colour).
The earliest editions in the series feature drawings by [[C. Walter Hodges]] that reconstruct the appearance of the plays when first produced in the [[Elizabethan theatre]]; this practice continued until Hodges' death in 2004.
Notable editions published in the series include the first ever edition of the disputed play ''[[Edward III (play)|Edward III]]'' to be published as Shakespeare's as part of a series; and a controversial edition of ''[[Pericles, Prince of Tyre]]'' that rejects the conventional thesis that the play was poorly printed and the result of [[collaborative authorship]].
The series also uniquely produces fully edited modern-spelling editions of [[quarto]] texts when they differ significantly from the standard received text of the play. These include editions of the [[Hamlet#Texts|first quarto of ''Hamlet'']], the [[Henry V (play)#Date and text|first quarto of ''Henry V'']], [[King Lear#Date and text|quarto ''King Lear'']], the [[Richard III (play)#Date and text|''Richard III'']], the quarto of ''[[Othello]]'', the [[Romeo and Juliet#Date and text|first quarto of ''Romeo and Juliet'']], and ''[[The Taming of a Shrew]]'', an alternate version of ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]''.
The general editors of the series are [[Philip Brockbank]] (1984-1990) and [[Brian Gibbons (scholar)|Brian Gibbons]] (1990-present), with individual editors, or pairs of, assigned to cover separate plays and poetry.
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.cambridge.org/features/ncs/ Official site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cambridge Shakespeare, The}} [[Category:Shakespearean scholarship]] [[Category:Cambridge University Press books]] [[Category:Series of books]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The Principles and Practice of Medicine: Designed for the Use of Practitioners and Students of Medicine''''' is a [[medical textbook]] by Sir [[William Osler]]. It was first published in 1892, while Osler was [[Professor]] of [[Medicine]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]]. The book established Osler as the world's leading authority in the teaching of [[modern medicine]].
The [[textbook|text]] was translated into French, German, Russian, Portuguese, Spanish and Chinese, and for over 40 years it was the world's most significant medical textbook.<ref>[http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/physicians/030002-2300-e.html Famous Canadian Physicians] at Library and Archives Canada</ref>
==References== *Golden, Richard. A history of William Osler’s ''The principles and practice of medicine''. Osler Library studies in the history of medicine No. 8. Montreal, McGill University, 2004. {{ISBN|0-7717-0615-4}}
==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/principlespract00osle First edition of the book, digitized for Archive.org by the University of Toronto]
==Footnotes== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Principles and Practice of Medicine}} [[Category:Medical manuals]] [[Category:History of medicine]] [[Category:1892 books]]
{{med-book-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Transport for London Group Archives''' is the official historical business archive for [[Transport for London]] (TfL) and its predecessor bodies. It preserves and makes available to the public documents, photographs, plans and drawings relating to the company and its predecessor bodies, such as [[London Regional Transport|London Transport]]. It is based at TfL headquarters building, 55 Broadway, built over [[St James's Park underground station]].
== History ==
London Transport did not appoint an archivist until 1992, by which time a significant volume of records had accumulated in the vaults under 55 Broadway since the opening of the first Victorian underground lines in the 1860s. With the formation of Transport for London in 2000, the corporate archives became the responsibility of TfL Group Archives and Records Management department.
== Material held ==
TfL Group Archives holds records from a large number of predecessor bodies, including: * The [[London General Omnibus Company]] * [[London County Council Tramways]] * [[London United Tramways]] * The [[Metropolitan Railway]] * The [[District Railway]] * The [[Central London Railway]] * The [[City and South London Railway]] * The [[Northern line|Great Northern and City Railway]] * The [[Hammersmith & City line|Hammersmith and City Railway]] * The [[Underground Electric Railways Company of London]]
Some of the records of predecessor companies, such as the Metropolitan Railway Company and early minutes from the [[London Passenger Transport Board]], are held on behalf of TfL by the [[London Metropolitan Archives]].
The majority of TfL Group Archives holdings are records of: * London Transport (in its various incarnations running 1933-2000) * Transport for London (2000–present day)
== Storage and access ==
Documents are stored offsite in the work-out parts of [[Winsford Rock Salt Mine]], [[Winsford]], [[Cheshire]], Britain's largest [[rock salt]] mine. The storage facility is operated by [[DeepStore Ltd.]],<ref>[http://www.deepstore.co.uk/ Welcome to Deep Store]</ref> a records' management company. Access to the archives is restricted and is by advance appointment only. TfL Group Archives catalogue of all records held will be made available online and searchable to the public.
== References ==
{{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.tfl.gov.uk/corporate/about-tfl/culture-and-heritage/corporate-archives?intcmp=2758 Transport for London Group Archives] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070702143500/http://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/Corporation/leisure_heritage/libraries_archives_museums_galleries/lma/lma.htm London Metropolitan Archives] * [http://www.ltmuseum.co.uk/ London Transport Museum] * [http://www.deepstore.com/ DeepStore]
{{coord|51|29|58|N|0|08|01|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}}

revision.text:
{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:German words and phrases]]}} '''''Umvolkung''''' ({{IPA-de|ˈʔʊmˌfɔlkʊŋ|lang}}) is a term in [[Nazi ideology]] used to describe a process of [[Cultural assimilation|assimilation]] of members of the [[Volksdeutsche|German people]] (the ''[[Volk]]'') so that they would forget about their language and their origin. As a [[neologism]], it echoes ''[[Umpolung]]'' "polarity inversion", leading to an interpretation akin to "ethnicity inversion".
The term is also used to describe the "re-[[Germanisation]]" of the German people, after new ''[[Lebensraum]]'' was conquered and the German people who already resided there would become more German again. Of course, Umvolkung in the first sense was seen as a negative process during the [[Third Reich]], while the second process was seen as desirable.
== Origin and background == The term was invented by [[Albert Brackmann]], a leader of the [[Ostforschung]], which was a research organization that investigated the character and the attitudes of people (the so-called "Verhalten") living in areas east of the German Reich, e.g. in Poland, Ukraine, Slovakia and Romania.
There was a plan to conquer almost whole Eastern Europe and process the "Umvolkung", so all the former German people, who had slowly assimilated and mixed with the other ethnicities, would become more German again.
== Today's use == The term became a catchphrase and is often used to describe German fears of ''[[Überfremdung]]'' by immigrants or their descendants whose numbers have been constantly increasing since the foundation of the [[German Federal Republic]].{{cn|date=January 2018}}
== Sources == * [http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/BEITRAG/essays/fami0500.htm] * [http://www.doew.at/projekte/rechts/chronik/1998_07/umvolker.html]
== See also ==
* [[Lebensraum]] * [[Generalplan Ost]] * [[Germanisation]] * [[Xenophobia]] * [[Volk]] * [[Glossary of Nazi Germany]]
